title: Holiday events promise scary fun
text:
Holiday events 
promise scary fun
Here’s a selection of blood-curdling events — movie screenings, parties and more — to enhance your Halloween celebration. 
40th Anniversary Screening of ‘The Rocky Horror Picture Show’ 
Drag superstars Peaches Christ and Latrice Royale will host a screening of the campy classic “The Rocky Horror Picture Show,” complete with audience participation and lots of yelling. Before the film, the world-class San Francisco Symphony will perform an hour of our favorite horror movie scores. Musical guests include thereminist Dorit Chrysler and “Beach Blanket Babylon’s” Shawna Ferris McNulty . Costumes are enthusiastically encouraged.
Oct. 31, 7:30 p.m. at Davies Symphony Hall, 201 Van Ness Ave., S.F. Tickets $15-$65. www.sfsymphony.com 
Phantasm: A Karnival
of Mischief
The spooky, sexy San Francisco Armory will be taken over by electronic music superstars Rob Garza from Thievery Corporation, the Polish Ambassador (the musician, not the actual ambassador to Poland) and Croatia Squad. The Vau de Vere Society will be blowing minds with its “subculture circus.” It’s definitely gonna get weird.
Oct. 31, 9 p.m. at the Armory, 1800 Mission St., S.F. Tickets $50. www.phantasmsf.com 
Ghost Ship VIII: Annihilation
Now in its eighth crazy year, Ghost Ship will feature original art installations by the leaders of the Bay Area’s dynamic large-scale production art community, and the world’s most exciting art cars. That’s right, these are Burning Man people. More than 70 local DJs will keep the beats flowing while artsy attendees attempt to outdo one another’s costumes.
Oct. 30-31, 9 p.m.-4 a.m., Pier 70, Building 12, 420 22nd St., S.F. Tickets TBD. www.ghostshiphalloween.com 
The Official Houdini 
Seance 2015
Harry Houdini actually performed at the Brava Theater in 1926. Now, 100 years after he performed at the 1915 Pan-Pacific International Exposition and 89 years after his stint on 24th Street, a collection of historians, mediums, comedians and magicians will discuss, celebrate and perhaps communicate with Houdini on the anniversary of his death.
Oct. 31, 8-10:30 p.m., Brava Theater, 2781 24th St., S.F. Tickets $39+. www.houdiniseance.com 
15th Annual ‘Halloween Hoopla’ Festival and Costume Parade 
Gouls, goblins and their ghastly parents are invited to attend this free festival in Yerba Buena Gardens. Families will brave a spooky palm reader, roaming clowns, a scary photo booth, Halloween crafts and the ever-popular costume contest, all designed for kids 10 and under.
Oct. 31, noon-1:30 p.m., Yerba Buena Gardens (Children’s Garden), 799 Howard St., S.F. Free. www.ybgfestival.org 
Castro Theatre Triple Feature
Horror flick fans and the antisocial (basically the same thing) can camp out all day in the gorgeous Castro Theatre for a bloody triple feature featuring “Night of the Living Dead” at 3:30, “The Texas Chainsaw Massacre” at 5:20 and “The Evil Dead” at 7 p.m.
Oct. 31, 3:30-9 p.m., Castro Theatre, 429 Castro St., S.F. Tickets $13. www.castrotheatre.com 
Freaky Tiki at the Tonga Room
San Francisco’s cheesiest high-end tiki bar is hosting a night of boozy potions, spooky snacks and an inexplicable celebrity lineup that is oddly appealing. Come dressed to win a Hawaiian grand prize in the costume contest hosted by Liam Mayclem and judged by ice champ Brian Boitano and TV anchor Vicki Liviakis. Stick around and dance the night away to beats provided by celebrity chef/DJ Hubert Keller .
Oct. 31, 9 p.m.-2 a.m., Tonga Room at the Fairmont Hotel , 950 Mason St., S.F. Tickets $45-$50. www.beatssf.com 
BATS Improv Presents ‘Halloween Horror Musical’
Few things are more terrifying than completely improvised comedy theater, and that’s just what’s in store at BATS Improv’s “Halloween Horror Musical.” The title is pretty self-explanatory, and the show will feature BATS’ talented cast of hilarious thespians. Guests in costume will get a free nonalcoholic beverage.
Oct. 30-31, 8 p.m., Bayfront Theater , B350, Fort Mason Center , S.F. Tickets $17-$20 www.improv.org 
City of Sausalito
Halloween Parade
The village of Sausalito loves Halloween even more than it loves charging tourists $40 for a T-shirt. Sausalito’s costumed kids parade is absolutely adorable and open to all kids, provided they show up on time. The city will also offer a kid-friendly (and a not-so-kid-friendly) haunted house, firefighters (real, not costumed) hot dog barbecue, and a sugar-packed trick-or-treat lane. Don’t miss the best part of this entire event: the Howl’O’Ween dog costume contest.
Oct. 31, 4:15 (parade starts at 6 p.m. sharp), Robin Sweeny Park, downtown Sausalito. Suggested donation $20 per family or $5 per person. www.ci.sausalito.ca.us 
24th Annual Pirates of Emerson Haunted Theme Park
The Alameda County Fairgrounds have once again been turned into a spooky field jam-packed with creepy mazes, roaming zombie pirates and suburban teens. This large-scale scary pirate theme park is not for the faint of heart, but it is for those who wish to be scared along with hundreds of sophisticated fright fans and a few dozen screaming girls in Uggs.
USS Hornet Monster’s Ball
The notoriously haunted aircraft carrier hosts its annual family-friendly Halloween soiree, where guests may or may not encounter actual ghosts. The popular Monster’s Ball serves as a fundraiser for the floating museum and will feature a professional haunted house, live music, a costume contest and spooky tours of the ship. (Our costume suggestion: a hornet.)
Oct. 31, 7:30 p.m.-1 a.m., USS Hornet, Pier 3, 707 W. Hornet Ave., Alameda. Tickets $30. www.uss-hornet.org 
— Beth Spotswood
